Award.AwardTitle: College of Engineering, Mathematics and Science Recruitment and Retention Center

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration: This NSF STEM Talent Expansion Program (STEP) project is increasing the number of students graduating with undergraduate STEM degrees through increased recruitment and retention of students in the College of Engineering, Mathematics, and Science (EMS), at the University of Wisconsin-Platteville. UW-Platteville, a STEM campus focused primarily on undergraduate education, serves over 7,400 students in a rural community. A Recruitment and Retention Center is being developed within the academic unit, which hosts tutoring and mentoring programs and also serves as a centralized location for College of EMS efforts; a significant focus is on supporting traditionally underrepresented STEM students. The STEP project builds on the success of existing programs, some of which are currently supported by the NSF. A structure is being provided to facilitate cohort development; increase networking opportunities including mentoring, advising and research; promote career development through internships and co-operative education; and support career selection and job placement. Students involved with the NSF STEP program are preparing for the 21st century workforce by participating in high impact practices including mentoring, internships, co-ops, scholarly engagements, workshops, service, outreach and conferences, which affect persistence and stimulate academic achievement excellence and career placements in STEM. Extensive analysis of the success of the programming offered through this STEP project is being conducted in order to increase the knowledge of best practices in the scholarship of teaching and learning. The number of STEM degrees awarded at UW-Platteville increases by over 20% by the end of this funding.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The College of Engineering, Mathematics and Science Recruitment and Retention Center project (STEP grant #116180) at the University of Wisconsin-Platteville resulted in several positive outcomes, including improved organizational infrastructure and expanded programming in youth STEM outreach, college student retention, and faculty retention.

 

Youth STEM Outreach

Grant staff were involved in launching a new program called Engineering, Mathematics, and Science Ambassadors. This program is a direct result of outreach partnerships and involvements that have developed during the grant period. The program consists of a team of undergraduate students who develop and conduct youth STEM outreach activities. Ambassadors communicate accurate information about STEM disciplines using appropriate messaging and are trained to work with individuals from diverse backgrounds and to develop activities that are inclusive and demonstrate the depth and breadth of STEM fields. Overall, during the grant period, approximately 3,200 youth in grades K through 12 participated in grant-related outreach events and activities.

 

College Student Retention

 

Retention Center Learning Space

As part of the grant initiatives, a study and resource space was created. The room, named CenterPOINT (Center for Projects, Opportunities, Instruction, Networking, and Teamwork), includes such features as: a full-time academic advisor/center manager; a front desk staffed by student assistants; free drop-in peer tutoring hours; tables on wheels that can be easily moved into different configurations; five computer stations; items available for checkout such as phone chargers, headphones, and calculators; a kitchenette space with refrigerator, microwave, and sink; wall-mounted and mobile white boards; soft seating; and cubby storage for books and personal belongings. The space comfortably seats approximately 34 people. See attached image.

 

To assess the effectiveness of the space, user demographics are collected and analyzed. Table 1 shows usage of the space CenterPOINT?s five operational academic years. Unique user numbers represent approximately one-third of College of EMS students.

 

Table 1: CenterPOINT Visitors

Year

Visits

Unique Visitors

Average Visits per Visitor

Academic Year 2013-14

816

Academic Year 2014-15

14,618

1,068

Academic Year 2017-18

14,630

1,082

14

 

Other measures include retention of the CenterPOINT users and their grade point averages as compared to their peers who do not use CenterPOINT. Students who use CenterPOINT retain to their next year of education at a rate of 86.6%, as compared to 73.7% of their peers who do not utilize the space. Students who utilize CenterPOINT have cumulative GPA?s that average 0.24 higher than their peers who do not use the space. 

 

Undergraduate Research & Travel

Another initiative of the STEP grant has been to implement an Undergraduate Research & Travel Grants program to support College of EMS students who are working on independent research and/or who wish to travel to professional conferences. Students who wish to receive support must submit a proposal application, which is then reviewed by a committee. In the five years of this program, support was provided to 300 students. As a condition of the funding support, students are asked to disseminate their research findings or knowledge gained at conferences on the campus community. This helps to encourage other students to pursue similar opportunities. Student participants also wrote a reflective summaries of how the experience enhanced their classroom learning. Portions of these activities have been institutionalized.

 

Career Exploration Industry Visits

By partnering with industry, the STEP grant was able to offer industry-led workshops on campus and also coordinate trips to corporate locations so that students could gain exposure to the working world and build their professional networks. In the five years of the grant, nine workshops and trips were coordinated with six different companies. 195 unique students participated in these events. 

 

STEM Study Skills

This STEP-supported project is a resource webpage for students to find help with general study skills and content-specific knowledge in courses with high withdrawal and fail rates. Worksheets, practice problems, and videos developed by UW-Platteville faculty are available on such topics as calculus, statics, physics, and circuits. https://www.uwplatt.edu/ems/study-skills

 

Faculty Support

Because quality of teaching and overall morale of professors can impact students? experience and therefore their retention, the STEP grant was able to support the implementation of a New Instructor Learning Community. This community helps new employees develop pedagogical skills, create and/or refine professional development plans, become comfortable with and knowledgeable about the UW-Platteville services and community, and develop a strong support network. Weekly meetings of the community are hosted by two tenured faculty members. The success of this community led to its adoption by administration at the University level.
